review_title: HR department is utterly impossible to deal with in all respects
pros: long-term stability and GREAT people. new york state's requirement to publish salary bands will probably be a pro come September 2023...
cons: There's one reason I want to leave UR, and it is HR. "equity" wins over filling positions. leads to understaffed in addition to overworked and underpaid. it's no wonder we have issues with retention and hiring. HR reps are exceedingly unhelpful and non-responsive. They refuse to give points of escalation for real, current, concrete and practical hiring issues. Basic processes are not documented. supporting salary information from glassdoor was dismissed as "unreliable self reported information" during an attempted - and partly successful - wage negotiation. Staff questions on benefits and policies can take months to get answers. Compensation is 30+% behind market for technical roles. Managers must do all their own recruiting and have no power over any of the hiring process, while having to do all the hard work of finding, screening and interviewing candidates, then stringing them along for weeks while some "compensation team" within the HR department decides how little you get to pay them.

review_title: University of Rochester lacks support for its research scientists
pros: If your going to work in academic research you are going to be poor so it helps to live somewhere with a low cost of living - Rochester NY is one such place - this is a major plus working at the University of Rochester and should be emphasized when the UofR goes recruiting . I had an opportunity to work go to work at Yale but could not afford to take the position as I could not support my family in New Haven on the pay I was offered. Besides being affordable Rochester is also an excellent place for families. Concerning the University of Rochester - at least in my old field of brain science the research community is extensive and strong and facilities are generally good.
cons: It is probably not unique to the U of R but I get the feeling that non-tenure track researchers are considered expendable resources. Support is completely  random - if you have a principle investigator who backs you up, great, other wise you are on your own. Ultimately, I don't really feel I worked for the U of R but rather that the U of R was my landlord and that I worked for the NIH who provided my funding.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Rochester, NY
pros: Any graduate student's experience depends greatly on the choice of advisor, but my experience here has been that many advisors (including my own) care about the welfare of their graduate students and don't generally try to take unfair advantage of them. Your success depends a lot on being assertive and confident, asking for (and often insisting on) the things you need.
cons: Many of the faculty in my department (Optics) are experienced, meaning that they tend to be busy and a little inaccessible, and they often have extremely high expectations for the amount of work needed for a PhD. It's one of the main factors contributing to a long time to degree (a particular issue in my department). Be forewarned that UR is dominated by the UR Medical Center, both specifically for research (it accounts for 75-80% of research dollars received by UR) and more generally (health care constitutes about 2/3 of UR's total revenue and at least that much of the upper administration's attention).

pros: The University of Rochester is a large organization that provides stability and good benefits.  It outwardly touts "community" as an important pillar and driving value, but seems to fall short in engaging its employees to help them feel more a part of one.
cons: Just as much as it can be construed to be a benefit, the size of the University of Rochester works against it (and even more so against its employees) in the form of bureaucracy.  Although a leading research University, ironically innovation in the workplace seems an ill-advised contribution.  The interpersonal climate of most offices with which I worked seemed shrouded by a lens of aristocracy and over-wielded condescension or patronization.  The result was that employees are left feeling more like a number that could never measure up, than an individual asset worth investing in.  Not much was/is done to identify, recognize, and enhance employee  strengths or accomplishment -- especially not in the form of promotions nor compensation.

review_title: Fine institution, however a little fascist about their wages and salary transparency
pros: Great people, phenomenal students. If you want a stable job it's fine, certainly. You could stay here for 20 years and never change what you were doing, if that's your thing.
cons: Impossible to get a raise, no matter how amazing you are as an employee. You can't even see what salary bands are because theyre so hush hush about it. This breeds complacency and burnout. HR hides behind "fairness" when really what Ive seen is top heavy management and ineffectiveness across the board - lots of overpaid Deans, Assnt Deans etc , VPs and Provosts of things who have hefty salaries and mobility. Meanwhile staff are hustling and burning out. So, if you're not on top...good luck?
