pros: Depends what department you're in, but I've never had a problem with flexing my schedule if necessary. Tuition waiver is amazing and almost one of the only reasons I'm here. Health benefits are better than average. 403(b) match is great, but only kicks in after 2 years of service.  Loads of opportunities to do continuing education via LEAN, various seminars, grand rounds, etc.
cons: VERY hard to move up in pay, even with promotions and job/title changes. There is a 10% cap on salary increases when changing positions or getting a promotion (so HR says, but there are plenty of people that make more than their salary range should allow and that defy the "rules" imposed by HR). This is very much a who-you-know culture, so if you do want to advance or get exposed to opportunities you really have to work at it and network hard. Leadership is somewhat aloof but I've found that immediate managers and middle management is available and reasonable. Biggest complaint is low salaries compared to the time and energy you're expected to devote.

review_title: Breath of fresh air! Very satisfied.
pros: Positive, people-oriented culture. Management shows appreciation and recognizes employee contributions. The mission of the University is meaningful - teaching, healing, discovering, performing -- making the world Ever Better.  It's inspiring. Work-life balance is supported.  Great benefits. Employee development is encouraged.  This is a refreshing change for those of us who have been fortunate enough to find a position at UR after years being ground down in the toxic environments of certain other local companies.
cons: Downsides are minor compared to the positives of working at UR. The university is decentralized, so it can be a challenge to get alignment and agreement.  Broad inclusion is necessary, and can slow progress, but taking the time to get buy-in leads to more successful results.  There are definitely opportunities to contribute because the university lags behind companies who have had to drive efficiencies through best practices.

review_title: Overall satisfying, although there is room for improvement regarding bureaucracy and some inconsistencies
pros: Great community, and some procedures and processes are regarded very highly. A large emphasis is placed on teamwork, leadership development, staff bonding - and the department invests quite heavily in training and developing positive staff relationships. Pay increases with the cost of college inflation and a small $50 bonus for each  returning year.
cons: Within the department there's a lot of bureaucracy, and some issues get put on the back burner until they become a crisis - or are handled after the issues more or less worked itself out with time, which defeats the purpose of some goals we generally have. There's also a lot of inconsistency across staffs within the department. Pay lacks other schools as only room rent is covered - some areas you end up being paid less because you're assigned a living area, but are then forced to get the largest meal plan and it's near impossible nowadays to appeal for a lower plan.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Rochester, NY
pros:
I can only comment on the Simon School of Business since that is where I work, but benefits are available to all UR and URMC faculty.

Good benefits, opportunities for promotion, and usually a more relaxed work environment. Working overtime isn't common, and the work environment is pleasant.
cons: Horrible parking situation. I get dropped off, so I can avoid parking, but there is no available on-campus parking anymore. You have to park offsite and take shuttle buses into work which adds an hour on to your work day (unpaid). On top of that frustration you still have to pay to park in the offsite parking lots. Pretty ridiculous in my opinion.

pros: Great benefits, as often the case with universities. Tuition benefits are fairly generous and a great opportunity, especially at a school of this caliber. The work/life balance is fantastic; summer hours are great and at the end of the day, it's not a stressful environment. Though the university doesn't close for holidays or offer extended breaks as often as others, vacation time is plenty. The campus is beautiful, it's a positive and progressive place to be.
cons: Higher ed and all its stereotypes about inefficient management are largely true. I've come to find base pay to be lower than average, and certainly lower than the majority of other colleges in the area for a similar job. Very few in upper level roles are talented managers or have been trained to manage; you may find your ability to grow in the organization is based upon the years you've spent there rather than the talent or work you've done.

review_title: University of Rochester - Once a great place to work.
pros: Benefits are still quite good compared to others, although in the last 11 years since I have been employed there they are slowly getting worse. 2015 has another change coming. The job security is good, but over the years it's gotten worse.
cons: From a salary standpoint UR is not a place to go if you're coming from a large blue chip and expecting to make the same salary. I was a IT Systems Analyst at Xerox/EDS making 65k in 2003 and took a position at UR for 48k. There is too much middle management within UR and the environment is very decentralized which leads to poor standards and processes within the company. Every group has their own processes and standards. Communication is poor within the company. Parking is terrible and you have to pay for it. Ticketing is rampant!!

review_title: UofR is on a down hill trend, used to be great benefits and lower pay... now its both
pros: Work environment and facility's were brand new, and they are constantly putting up new buildings. You do end up supporting meaningful work in the medical field.
cons: You pay for parking!! and its not even high quality or close to where you work. It can even cause late arrivals due to overflows for the lot you again paid to have a spot!

pros: Great customers, promotes from within, groom and train their employees, some of the best benefits i have ever had, and most of my higher ups get the bigger picture, the hard part is getting the employees to understand and see the bigger picture that is not just an 8 hour gig, you have to be compassionate and maintain a positive attitude daily.
cons: In a giant organization it is difficult to set yourself apart from the crowd, and most times what makes sense and is logical won't be what we end up having to do, since the university just wants to save face 99% of the time.

pros: If you are poking around for the reputation of U of R, then rest assured that the faculty are some of the best.
cons:
Very slow to adapt to technology.
Top level management have been sitting in their positions for years--there is a limit to how far you can advance in this company.
CEO and President Seligman is running the whole show into the ground. Between gentrifying the ward and his pet projects (ex. he bought a ferry for river tours; had to sell it after 2 years), he needs to go SOON.
Management is eager to fire you; they document every interaction and you're screwed if you don't submit letters documenting your perspective too.

pros: Cafe, exercise, nice coworkers,closer to hoome
cons: Rochester Tech Park is a farm. open floor plan next department 10 feet away. everyone watches everyone and tells ALL that they see even if on break or lunch, none of that is considered, if they see it they tell it. Nothing is confidential. if you want to apply for another dept your current supervisor is told and then given the opportunity to give their "personal opinion" about you. so if they have some sort of issue with you, forget about it. leadership doesn't know how to lead from a true leadership perspective, everything you do is suspect and your questioned from an already guilty position. I can go on and on! its just bad. if you really need a job BAD i say hey apply, but if not don't. even if

review_title: Prestigious university, affordable city, admin static
job_title: Science Graduate Student in Rochester, NY
pros: U of R is a pretty prestigious place in many fields, including mine.  In the sciences, you're always funded, and life in Rochester on around $20K a year isn't too bad - a lot of grad students end up owning homes here. Overall, it's not a bad place to be.  Great Restaurants in the city.  Lousy on-campus food.
cons: The admin can sometimes provide annoyance - randomly deleting your web site, levy small (or occasionally large) random charges, having a few strange policies.

pros: I've been extremely fortunate to work with some amazing people over the past 30 years, many of whom have become lifelong friends.  Nearby College Town is wonderful; easy to walk up for a quick lunch, or just stroll and window shop.
cons: Having to pay for horrible parking tops the list.  The culture at UR has become to refuse pay raises (outside of  the ridiculous 2% annual [if you walk on water] increase) and deny promotions while simultaneously doubling the workload.  Senior leadership and HR could not care less.  iCare is a complete farce.

review_title: Absolutely loved the past 5 years here. I'm going to miss my group very much as well as management.
job_title: Operations Tech III in Henrietta, NY
pros: For me- the tuition benefit was insane- 90% reimbursement or waiver. My MBA cost around $100,000- I will graduate debt free. Professional environment, many resources, great management- large university with room for growth. Health benefits.
cons:
Not many- besides I guess it can be difficult to move around he university. Their online job platform leaves much to be desired. It's also very difficult to get hired by the university in general. 

Non-for-profit work can also leave you stuck financially in a rut. For profit companies tend to pay their employees a higher wage- annual raises are laughable. Need to reward long term employees better- 

Poor dental and health benefits in comparison to other companies.

job_title: Higher Education Professional Staff in Rochester, NY
pros: Great benefits, including healthcare, tuition and retirement.  Many front line staff and faculty are wonderful to work with.
cons: Salary is much lower than industry and regional standards even with benefits accounted for.   Due to lower salary and lack of development opportunities quality staff leave and many middle managers are not properly supported.  Strategic leadership is not prevalent in non academic units.   Overall, administration does not seem to value the bulk of employees that do the daily work.

review_title: Great benefits, expect it to become better
pros: Health insurance is amazing, a lot of starting vacation, many great people throughout the organization and overall not a bad working climate. I am optimistic about the leadership of the University's new President Sarah Mangelsdorf.
cons:
Many organizations within the college are bureaucratic, territorial, and run by people who have no business being in their roles.

Until Coronavirus the organization has not had to think too hard about the efficacy of its resource allocation.

review_title: Despite what they say UofR DOES NOT CARE about their employees
pros:
You can get reduced tuition for yourself or family after a year.
Good health insurance.
cons:
Consistently pushed to work more than 40 hours when salaried. 
Most people buy into working more hours (60-80), subsequently most of your co-workers are miserable.
Can not take advantage of the education benefit because you are too busy working.
Management thinks they are an aristocracy.
Management is more interested in making sure you are under your thumb than getting a job done. 
Complaining to larger HR comes back to bite the employee.
There is no parking.
You have to pay for a parking permit.
Even though the pay is not enough to survive on in Rochester and you still have to get a second job, the employee is expected to make UofR the top priority in their life. No work life balance here.

review_title: Great workplace, good food and people
pros: A lot of support for the worker in terms of training, people that help you with your work. Lots of  freebies, opportunity to advance if there if you have a full time job and the education. Facilities are up to date and its always warm in doors! which means a lot with Rochester weather.
cons: If you are working as a student, there is little effort to welcome you and really settle you in, lack of effort from employer and student employees. Its a depressing city, seems to have rubbed off onto the employees, a lot of gossip, not much going on. Compensation was well above minimum for students.

review_title: No good culture in the ECE department, be cautious to choose an advisor in this department
pros: Some departments have good cultures. A very small, private university is also a plus in some circumstances.
cons: Dictatorship in many groups of ECE department, so you have to choose a good advisor and expect him/her to behave well consistently. Be sure to avoid some professors; to do this, you'd better first talk to some students there before you accept an offer. Cold weather in the city over a half of the year. Boring small city.

pros:
- Positive work culture has been instilled.
- Excellent supply room
- Premier research faculty.
- Access to downtown Rochester.
- One of the strongest laser facilities in the entire country.
- Paid high school internship
- Accommodating senior management. 
- Solid tech support
- Highly private and collaborative
cons:
- Located in Rochester, NY
- Lack of work-out/exercise facility
- Poor dining options in the building
- Restrictive dress code
- Bureaucratic red tape
- Inflexible provided technologies
- Pay is only minimum wage
- Limited future career opportunities
- Cultural reforms being overturned rapidly
- Privacy being infringed upon

review_title: Great perks, but I was spread too thin
job_title: Applications Administrator and Analyst in Rochester, NY
pros:
- Always something interesting going on
- Fantastic benefits (health care, tuition reimbursement, etc.)
- Diverse work culture
- Generally friendly coworkers
cons:
- Pay is underwhelming
- Departments are decentralized, so getting information where it needed to go was a clumsy process
- I was the only person in the department with tech-related responsibilities, but my functional resources were spread too thin and I burned out; there was no budget for personnel-based assistance

review_title: good job security, but a lot of baggage
pros: great retirement and vacation accrual. Good benefits in a very stable environment.  All management I have worked with have been supportive and very smart.  I have always felt appreciated.
cons: Not quick to change.  A lot of old guard and not a lot of emphasis on creativity. Big projects take forever and setbacks seem more prevelant than in the private sectors I've worked in.  Pay is not great compared to the same positions in a for profit. It would be great to see them adopt some workplace trends like telecommuting one day a week and adaptation of more flexible hours.

review_title: Big Bureaucracy with no advancements after your hire
pros: Great benefits package for health and personal education.  403B is a good plus as well.
cons: What they do not tell you is once you are hired into a position, no matter how well you do you must wait a minimum of 2 years for promotion eligibility.  If you desire to transfer to another department in the same position, there is no wage adjustment allowed.  You do more work for the same pay.  There is no budget for training or personal development to position you for a promotion either.  Poor cross-departmental relationships.  Recent lay-offs, hiring freeze, and salary freeze are discouraging.

pros: Reasonably good benefits,  although that seems to be changing with the implementation on new FLSA legislation coming soon.  Beautiful campus and friendly people.
cons: Salary is 20% less than that at other local institutions for the same position.   It's so out of balance with peer institutions that it's simply a joke.   Jaded upper administration cling to philosophy centered upon people "wanting"  to work at UR for relatively low salary due to prestige.

review_title: Laboratory for Laser Energetics of a great place for a grad student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Rochester, NY
pros: The lab really cares about its graduate students and their outcomes. The research can be done nowhere else except national labs. All the graduate students have an easy time finding employment in National labs or the private sector upon Ph.D. compilation. The pay is also pretty good for a grad student.
cons: It's a big lab and sometimes your publications can be at the mercy of engineering and facility scheduling. Lucky the lab makes it a priority to get grad students what they need to graduate in a good position.

pros: Great culture for promoting personal growth.  The University fosters a philosophy that allows staff to continue their education and evolve their skills.  It sits in a community where family is important and family obligations are respected.  The freedom to manage our time is valued by me and most of my peers.
cons: Very staid and slow to change.  The University has trouble taking risks.  Its culture is somewhat insular and failures, even quite small ones, are strictly avoided.  This slows growth to a crawl and stifles creativity and advancement in technology.   Unfortunately, this is cultural and not necessarily connected to individual leaders.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Rochester, NY
pros: The Ph.D. program in biomedical engineering at the University of Rochester provides excellent training opportunities. In addition, the salary is very competitive, especially considering the low cost of living in Rochester.
cons: The Ph.D. program in biomedical engineering at the University of Rochester has the largest course load of any Ph.D. programs at the university. Graduation times typically exceed 5 years.

review_title: Excellent place to advance career within education and communications
pros: Great flexibility, excellent pay especially as you climb the ranks, recognition of boss and co-workers when jobs completed well and on time, stress free, no competition, excellent benefits, work for a top tier university, great if pursuing education as future career, opportunity for various travel experiences depending on what sector you work for
cons: There are times when there may not seem like much to do, but if you are independent and a hard worker, you will find things to accomplish.  Not everything is "spoon fed" to you which may or may not be a downside to working there. Not much else

job_title: Teaching Assistant/Workshop Leader in Rochester, NY
pros: Working with other students to help them solve problems has been really fun. Also having to lead a workshop on select material really reinforces your own understanding of it.
cons: Having worked in both mandatory and optional workshop environments, neither feels very good. Students can easily resent having to come to mandatory workshops, and it can be difficult to get them to have a good time. On the other hand, it can be frustrating having nobody show up to optional workshops when you know they're not doing well.

pros: There is absolutely no benefit at working at the University of Rochester
cons: A bunch of crazy people acting like they are god. I have a million examples-expecting to be on a call 24/7, getting yelled at if you weren't able to answer the phone after work hours (as late at 11 pm). One of the most ridiculous things I remember is that at an event when we stopped at subway there were turkey and ham sandwiches and they ran out of turkey so I offered just to buy myself a turkey sandwich because I don't eat ham for religious reasons and my supervisor literally yelled at me and told me to "humble" myself just cause I didn't want to eat ham.

pros: The benefits and vacation time are impressive when first starting out.  There is also a lot of flexibility with time off, such as for appointments.  The work is rewarding and there are many passionate people I enjoy working with.
cons: The pay is not comparable to other companies in the area and the parking can be very difficult/expensive.  It is best to work here if you take advantage of the tuition benefits, as that can make a huge difference.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Rochester, NY
pros: I've held positions in a few different departments and the connections you make with professors are wonderful. I was given the opportunity to lead groups of students, helping them and providing advice, which was very rewarding.
cons: The pay-to-time-committed varies greatly, and you won't know the amount until you've committed unless you ask previous TAs.

review_title: The department is great place for postdoc
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Rochester, NY
pros: Don't have pressure for my research. The instruments are in good shape. The faculty and staff are very nice. The restaurants in the river campus are very nice. I like the Friday 5 dollars buffet.
cons: The parking lot is kind of far from the building, especially during the cold winter. And the river campus is by the side of public cemetery, which makes me little uncomfortable.

pros: You can work with some brilliant professors at UofR. With the payment level, one can easily afford housing and support their families. Really close to finger lakes and national park.
cons: The weather is horrible during winter, unless you like snow. I personally find that it is really hard to get to work on snowing days. No matter how heavily it is snowing, you need to go to work. So, make sure you bring your shovel with you.

job_title: Senior Programmer Analyst in Rochester, NY
pros:
Rochester is a very cultural city with great public suburban schools and cheap housing. Commute for most people is short. These are huge advantages of living in Rochester.
I also like my work environment at U of R and people I work with.
cons: A job market is bad in Rochester. HR of U of R uses this situation for "no promotion" policy. Benefits are also worsened significantly.  "Expensive medical care" is an official reason, but U of R is self insured with its own hospital.

pros: You get to work with the customers (e.g. students, faculty, etc.) and gain helpful hands on knowledge of the University digital systems.
cons: Most of the problems are very common and repeat often. A lot of times, the solutions are found within the first 5 minutes of interaction with the customers. Very low knowledge ceiling. At least the learning curve isn't bad.

pros: Lots of room to learn and grow as you work. You get to work at one of the most exceptional music schools in the country, so if you cherish that opportunity you can make a real difference.
cons: The University itself has an incredibly complex bureaucratic nature, although this may not be a con for some. If you want to excel during your time at ESM you need to learn how to navigate the red tape. Technologically behind by several years.

pros: It is an amazing work environment between the students and professional staff that you work with. You receive awesome goodies at the beginning and the end of the summer, and the work is very rewarding. There is no specific role to fill, each summer the positions are entirely different depending on the staff hired, so there are many opportunities to do tasks that suit your talents. There are also great networking opportunities throughout the summer.
cons: The week of Orientation is high stress and long hours. If that is not something that is easy to handle, this is not the job for you.

review_title: Great Experience to Start a Career in Academia
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Rochester, NY
pros: If you are a foreign student, this is the best way to get introduced to the American education system and style. It is quite different from the rest of the world. Working with experienced Professors, you study the best practices.
cons: I do not see any cons. It was a job to start career in academia. Everything was great. All professors were friendly and helpful.

review_title: A great experience and resume builder for university students!
job_title: International Interviewer At the Office of Admissions in Rochester, NY
pros: Friendly office, invested supervisor who gives feedback and communicates regularly, flexible work schedule, work from home (interviewing  prospective international students for the university), skill building (writing reports, speaking with students, analyzing interviewees), interesting to hear perspectives of students from all over the world, helped me become a better conversationalist and a better listener
cons: Quota had to be met and work hours were extreme depending on the time zone of the student (7am interview for me = 3pm for the interviee), not much interaction with office staff, not much interaction with fellow interviewer colleagues

review_title: Top 10 company to NOT work for.
pros: Finger lakes coffee, high turn over rate.
cons:
Very low pay, management will remind you that you are easily replaceable, don't care about patient safety.  Paying for parking, parking lots are always full, taking a shuttle which adds an hour of unpaid time.  Construction 24/7. HR refuse to return calls.  Did i mention low pay?  Very dirty environment.  Paying to park and having to give them your keys to move your vehicle.   People stealing from your vehicle when they move it.
 Often bill items that are never even used.  They only care about money.

pros: The work environments are generally very friendly.  People in computer-related positions are generally allowed to make their own work environment, decide on work hours and telecommuting with their direct supervisors.
cons: The salaries are poor compared to private industry, but probably average for an academic institution.  Some employees need to find their own funding for their jobs, so "permanent" positions are sometimes more like contract work.

job_title: Applications Developer Intern in Rochester, NY
pros: It is very structured, you know what projects you have to work on and when they want them to be done. You are invited to all business meetings and get to sit in on conversations with clients. They give you a lot of work to do so you don't get board. At the end of the internship, you get to present your work on a poster in a Q/A session.
cons: You don't get to see other interns. Every intern is assigned a team with full time employees. You see the other interns at events but you never work with them.

job_title: Graduate House Advisor in Rochester, NY
pros:
- Great staff and phenomenal supervisor!
- Living so conveniently in the middle of campus makes it easy to get to classes. 
- Bus system is easy to use 
- Rewarding when programming sticks
- Only have duty twice a semester 
- Public Safety always has your back
cons:
- Fraternity men can be difficult to work with because many of them feel entitled and have not been told no often before. 
- FSA and ResLife don't always talk to each other

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Brighton, Erie, NY
pros: Can't think of anything at this time. Watched a primary care dr's office that ran like a well-oiled machine, go in the dumpster in the course of a year due to a bad choice in new office manager. Huge turnover,sooo many have left, including me after over a decade of service.
cons: Unprofessional and unqualified office manager.

pros: Provided me with work experience, experience with ResLife in particular, and housing for the summer, and I worked about ten hours per week.
cons: There is not always a lot to do, or the tasks can seem very menial, but they have to be done. At the end of the summer the job can become very stressful, as students are arriving back on campus.

pros: Stable for the most part. Lots of opportunity to change positions, however that may mean changing departments.
cons: Compensation is below average. Culture is toxic. There is no unified vision or goal for the future across the university, which makes growth, and sometimes even functioning normally, nearly impossible. Response to being regularly short staffed is to tell everyone to work more. Bad apples are often dealt with by promoting up and out.

job_title: Technical Assistant III in Rochester, NY
pros: positive group of people that allow work to be flebile as long as it gets done in time, and you maintain a decent level of responsiveness.
cons: hmmmm not really sure on this one. the winter in rochester for one thing, though this isn't really a part of the university

review_title: Miss the students and other departments, but glad I left
pros:
Beautiful campus.
Attracts intelligent, talented students, professors, caring staff.
Curriculum and educational environment - I had the opportunity to experience and learn something new everyday.
Active employees & wellness opportunities - softball leagues, fitness challenges, Chase corporate challenge 5K participation, free biometric screenings with $100 or $125 incentives, etc.
Student-focused collaboration among departments.
Opportunities to do more than just your job description, like be a pre-major advisor, help out during Orientation, advise/coach a club or organization, etc.
cons:
HR policies and management actively contribute to a very toxic work environment and a feeling of being unappreciated. I didn't realize this fully until after I left the university. For a research university that inherently attracts naturally happy, creative, and mentoring professionals, it takes a lot of HR incompetence to create that kind of negative atmosphere. Here are some ways this was achieved in my department:

1) The dean of my department at every year's all-staff meeting would give a speech emphasizing that employees will always come last in our mission. Customer service is first followed by university goals followed by (if possible) employee satisfaction. (Those to find themselves in a 'mentoring' or 'education' profession are typically not in it for the glory or the chance to come before the people they serve.)

2) Upon completing the self-performance evaluation at every 6-month interval, I was routinely told by my supervisor to go back and change my responses and give myself lower ratings to better align with the overall average of the department. Not sure if this is just a really bad supervisor trying to sabotage my accomplishments and any hopes I'd have for a promotion or if it was really bad direction from HR given to a middle-management supervisor.

3) Data isn't used when reviewing performance and when creating targets for future years. Flexible work schedules (for salaried employees who work all hours anyway) provided upon peer approval. One peer redirecting their dissatisfaction could prevent your request from for a flexible schedule, not only is it not granted but this feedback is then used against you in performance reviews. 

Also -
Expensive payroll deductions and benefits. Though it takes 15 minutes to walk from your parking spot to your office location, the costs for employee parking is in the ballpark of $500+ per year. The previous institution where I worked cost $25 for parking for the year, free for motorcycles, and the institution I attended for undergrad had free parking for all employees.

No p-cards. Employees who have to travel extensively for business trips have to pay for it with their own available credit and get reimbursed 3 weeks after all of their receipts are turned in. UR doesn't reimburse for interest charges or late fees, therefore it's like turning your employees into a personal credit card without paying them interest. Not sure if this is illegal but it should be.

review_title: They keep growing, but offering less and less to employees
pros: Lots of opportunities to move to another department or position.  Hires from within frequently.  Fairly good job security - unless you are at the top, or really mess up.  Benefits are decent, even though they are not as good as they use to be and could be better.
cons:
No more free tuition for employees, OR their children.  It used to be free for employees, and after 10 years free for their kids as well.  That was  IF they could get accepted and met all kinds of criteria.   Then,  this changed to employees paying a percentage, and after 10 years their children would pay the same price as a SUNY school, with even more rules to get accepted.  I know at least a few employees that  worked here for many years,  made sure their child met all the rules and standards, only to discover their child was not accepted.   There was no reason other than it was a competitive year.  There is no recourse.  No other options.  It's a huge dangling carrot.   Other area colleges, like RIT, have much better tuition benefits.  After only 5 years, your child can go to RIT for FREE, without all the rules and criteria.  If your child does not want to go to RIT, there is a Tuition Exchange Program with hundreds of other colleges and RIT will pay 80% tuition at one of them for your child.  

Health benefits also fading.  Few plans to pick from, and more expensive, and covering less and less.   If you don't go to a U of R doctor, you are penalized and charged far more for everything, regardless of the type of plan you pick .  This was not the case a few years ago.  

Departments vary considerably, as far as how employees are treated and working conditions.  This can even greatly vary within departments, depending on the position.   Some departments have a large disconnect between faculty and staff.  

Raises and pay are not that great - at least for staff.  For being the #1 employer in Rochester,  they seem to be getting more and more cheap with employees.  Expecting good workers to do the work of two people, or take a job for less pay than they are worth.  Because there are so many people looking for work, they get away with it. 

Meanwhile, employees / managers that are obviously not doing a good job, and have possibly been brought to management and HR's attention, get a free ride indefinitely.   Nobody wants to rock the boat or deal with any issues.   "Like it or Lump it" (or leave it) type attitude.

review_title: I'm enjoying a professionally satisfying career and great benefits.
pros: Excellent benefits and opportunities for professional education and development. Encouragement to lead and effect improvements. Opportunities to interact with the University and Medical Center community.
cons: LImited opportunities for advancement within some divisions. Low pay in proportion to expectations and responsibilities. Wide variation in levels of motivation and effectiveness of management.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Rochester, NY
pros:
Low cost of living in the area. 

Students are cooperative and friendly. 

Graduate student seminars aimed at future faculty and non-academic jobs (however these are usually aimed at larger departments like biology, medicine, and engineering; I've never found any to be useful). 

Interesting research in many fields, though few stand out as leaders.
cons:
Individuals seem to care about your research and you as a person, but overall, graduate students are stuck in a social, administrative, and academic purgatory that makes a PhD hell. 

There are very few postdocs here, making a big gap in the scientific machine. Graduate students are used as slave labor to fill that gap and end up taking a very long time to graduate (at least in the humanities and hard sciences/math, not sure about soft sciences). 

The quality of matriculated graduate students has plummeted over the years. Good students are accepted but very view decide to attend. This means you have to struggle with poorly prepared and/or poorly motivated coworkers and/or employees. 

Funding for my department (hard sciences) was awful in terms of university facilities, my lab's research funding, department funding for students, everything. It was impossible to keep up with research elsewhere because of this. 

Interdisciplinary work is touted but in practice difficult to achieve due to insufficient funding. 

There are too many undergraduate students enrolling in technical majors so service courses (intro calculus, physics, engineering, etc) can't keep up and the quality has suffered. "Self-paced" seems fancy but it is a disaster. (The workshop courses are great though.) 

Administrative staff is hit or miss. Many are exceptional but many can barely use a computer. 

Student health insurance lacks useful benefits and the required on-campus health center is laughably unprofessional in terms of patient interaction and in medical knowledge. 

Career center only gives advice aimed at undergraduates, premeds, and business majors. 

Undergraduate students are by and large rich and arrogant and not diverse, interesting, nor hardworking; that's probably true of most private schools though. 

...most of those issues are not unique to UR, but these issues are well known and UR isn't doing anything to combat them.

pros: Good benefits, great students, strong mission of student support, great colleagues.
cons: Advancement management turnover, post-campaign, has not been strong.  Morale is low, and general feeling of a lack of support for employees is prevalent.  Self-interest in restructure also evident.  Power consolidated to protect some, eliminate others.  Values are only for some, and when convenient - not well-modeled by senior managers.

review_title: I feel good work at University of Rochester
job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Rochester, NY
pros: good work environment and put a lot on faculty development. the University rank is good and also city Rochester is ranked in top 3 for raising family.
cons: if you could get enough funding and you will be fine, and if you could not get funding support you will be out and no any support from University.

review_title: Laboratory for Laser Energetics: Great mentorship for student employees
pros: One of the primary missions of the LLE is student learning and experience. As a student working at the LLE, I had several opportunities for great mentorship. The projects are always engaging and hands-on, the hours are flexible, and my coworkers are helpful and friendly. Great experience to put on your resume, this place is like a scientist's playground with expensive equipment highly accessible. I highly recommend the LLE to any student!
cons: Experiments and research can move at a slow pace.

review_title: Great experience as a student worker
job_title: IT Center Employee in Rochester, NY
pros:
As a student worker, working for IT, I was able to make money on the side while helping out my peers. 
Great supervisors were very understanding and supportive
Got great experience with professional technical skills 
Fits very well into schedule. Very easy to maintain the hours you need with the workload you have.
cons: The university has a very disjoint HR department which can cause problems and headache if one has multiple jobs.

review_title: employment full time in Parking Services Dept.
job_title: Parking Services Representative in Rochester, NY
pros: I work for parking services dept. and it has able overtime to work. We are a very diverse bunch of people so everyone has a say on what goes on our dept. Free lunch once a month, awards for attendance and yearly increases. Inexpensive health and dental.
cons: Working outside does has it's drawbacks. Cold and Heat and Rain.

review_title: School and Studies - Hand in Hand
pros:
As a student, there are many work studies you can partake in. 
It is so easy to get employment on campus, whether it be in a TA position, in a foodservice position, or at one of the many libraries. 
There are always opportunities for advancement.
cons: The tuition is expensive as all hell. As a student, you start with the lowest pay. It can be exhausting to go through all of the required trainings you will have to complete if you are hired and taking classes.

review_title: Horrible place to start your career, if you are looking for a place to hang out till retirement it is awesome!
pros: Not a lot of work gets done so if you like being lazy its pretty good.  Ok benefits and good work schedule flexibility and time off.
cons: Horrible pay, horrible opportunities for advancement.  People are entrenched in their jobs and don't like change.  A lot of inept employees/management.

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Rochester, NY
pros: Amazing access to facility and extremely nice people in general. Students are always willing to learn and they are even ready to help you if needed. Highly recommend
cons: Can be a bit posh sometimes, given their slowly rising ranking. Science faculty get priority over others which can sometimes be annoying (but from an economics respective--understood).

review_title: Good place to work but lower than average pay
pros: Benefits are great.  Starting vacation time is a little over three weeks.  Heath care is great with reasonable monthly costs.  The work environment is not as stressful as it could be.  Most everyone I work with are very positive.
cons: The pay is much lower than industry average.  The chance for advancement seems limited and seems to only be achievable with time or how much paper you have behind your name.   Dental coverage isn't the best.

review_title: Be careful to select your PhD advisor in ECE department
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Rochester, NY
pros: small department, small university, you probably can get attention and help from your PhD advisor
cons: in ECE department, a professor decides everything for his/her student, and therefore it is very risky for your career if your advisor him/herself has a problem. Some professors there are not nice and helpful, some are really good, and you need to very careful about this.

pros: Generally good collegiality encouraged by admin. Benefits. Salary ok. Tuition benefits
cons: Politics can be nasty and admin tries too hard to stay out of the mix relying on people to step up and solve their own problems (not effective).

review_title: Long and hard hours at UofR
pros: University of Rochester is a rewarding place to work.  I have learned many skills there and the pay and benefits are excellent.
cons: The academic lifestyle is demanding and requires many hours of hard work. My worst complaint is that the bathrooms were dirty more often than not.

review_title: Great to work  for a University
pros: Very good benefits and working conditions.  Vacation and time off policy very generous.  Benefits and salary very good.
cons: Union workers outside the medical staff are paid too well.  A lot of the non-medical staff should not be union or the university should out-source those positions.

review_title: University of Rochester @ LLE- Be ready to work hard and expand your knowledge base
pros:
- Majority are willing to answer questions and provide teachable moments
- Great communication and task assignment
- Able and encouraged to push the limits in research
- Great Health and Safety program
- Strong work community (picnics monthly and holiday events)
cons:
- Some people are so focused on their individual work they forgot they are in a large facility encompassing diverse research causing personality conflicts 
- Co-workers can be elitist about titles

pros: A great opportunity to help fellow students while pursuing your own studies. I find it useful to work with world class faculty and a great honor to be asked to be a teaching assistant.
cons: None so far. In the limited time I have worked in this position I have not encountered any downsides.

pros: The department of Immunolgy and Vaccinology was a great place to work. Everyone was very friendly and helped you get done whatever you needed to get done. Would be glad to work for them anytime.
cons: The winters are very cold and you need to get used to snow. You also have to pay for parking which isn't cheap.

review_title: Very low pay, high turnover.  Poor morale.
job_title: Technical Associate II in Rochester, NY
pros: Cutting edge scientific research, oppurtunity to get published.
cons: Very low pay, no upward mobility or promotion based on good preformance.  High dissatisfaction among other employees.  Research employees are paid out of grant money, so investigators try to get as many people for as little pay as possible.  No respect for life outside of work, expected to work long hours for no additional overtime pay.  Employees are salaried at the lowest possible salaries, only so they do not have to pay overtime while they require more than 8hr workdays regularly.

pros: Benefits are great as well as my working environment.  Not all departments are the same.
cons: Parking!  Parking can be very expensive, depending on where you work within the University.  Even the closest lots are quite a walking distance and the highest priced.

pros: it's a small environment so it's easy to form collaborations with strategic partners
cons: needs to be more innovative and forward-thinking to compete with other universities. they need to admit a more intellectual student body.

pros:
Independence given to teams to run their own show.
Interaction with the students - generally a very smart and motivated group.
cons: Large organization - can be very bureaucratic and a little impersonal.  Rules won't be bent for you, which makes sense most of the time, but occasionally leaves you scratching your head.

review_title: Very quick to pigeon hole those that do thier job very well and not offer opportunities for advancement
pros: The benefits are actually pretty decent.
cons: Not enough supervision of hiring practices of department staff within the UofR.  People have been hired without any job postings which has results in biased staff hires.

job_title: Technical Assistant III in Rochester, NY
pros: Good work environment, not high stress (though it can vary a bit from lab to lab). U of R values it's employees and the well-being. I've heard one labtech complain that the health insurance plans aren't great, but personally I don't see a problem. I can't speak to the benefits, since I don't get any as a student.
cons: Not the greatest resources, I feel like I've outgrown my position, which is why I'm applying to graduate school.

job_title: Various Temp Jobs in Rochester, NY
pros: Great health benefits and vacation time. Met  some very nice people. Most offices I worked at were pleasant because I worked as a temp for 2 years.
cons: Only place I know where you have to pay for parking to work there. Pay raises are low 2%. some offices are to clicky.

pros: The opportunity for continued education is really great. Definitely a convenient place to work where you can easily access your physician, dentist, pharmacy, bank, post-office, all in one building complex.
cons: Parking is terrible, the cost and inconvenience of parking is very high.  Tickets for not being perfectly within spaces are also annoying. There is not at all enough parking.

pros: few - tuition benefits are the ONLY reason to take a position with the University
cons: Rude Students, ANCIENT TECHNOLOGY making record management tedious, the University has grown to be huge entity in Rochester and treats employees like a number. Parking is expensive and add an additional 20 minutes to your commute because it is not nearby. Pay is minimal at best and there is little to no room for growth.

job_title: Classroom Technology Employee in Rochester, NY
pros: Staff is kind and helpful. Hours and pay were reasonable. Classroom Technology feels like a community rather than just a job.
cons: Some late night hour were needed. Expect to have a lot of difficulty finding someone to cover for you come exam time.

review_title: Being a Graduate Student at the University of Rochester
pros: Flexible hours, supportive professors, wide range of classes, investment in area with college town, lots of activities a short distance away, lots of support for graduate students from writing to classes
cons: Winter is half the year, can be very isolating because of cold, parking is terrible, did I mention it's cold a lot?

pros:
There are a wide variety of student jobs. 

It is difficult to manage a balance between work and school. Thankfully, all of my employers have been understanding of this, and have been fairly flexible to accommodate my academic needs.
cons: The compensation for many student jobs is not great, and getting a job with work study is very (unnecessarily) competitive.

pros: Working for mail services at the University of Rochester is great. The hours are fantastic (7-330) and the people are very nice. Great for somebody looking for a job.
cons: Must have a CDL-B license. Requires a lot of walking and driving in bad weather.

job_title: Technical Associate I in Rochester, NY
pros: Decent pay for academic work but lower than industry.  Provides good benefits such as dental, health, and tuition reimbursement for classes related to your work.
cons: Parking is a nightmare and costs a substantial amount  that is not included as a benefit.  Good working conditions, good co-workers.  Due to the nature of academia job security can be a concern as many labs have been losing funding due to grants getting cut back.

pros: Good and free environment. Flexible working hours. It is located in a very quiet space. Not far from univerisity of rochester.
cons: There is not place to eat within the Laboratory so you have to bring your own food or use a car for lunch. There is no free parking lot for employee.

review_title: Great Benefits, Not very competitive pay
job_title: Ambulatory Clinical Technologist in Rochester, NY
pros: Great Benefits Including tuition, 401K, health care plans, and discounts for local businesses.
cons: Pay is not very competitive for the area.  There are no opportunities for advancement in positions.  There are department with high turnover due to poor management/administration.  It is also very hard to apply for jobs and expect any sort of response back to applicants.

review_title: An outstanding institution by all standards.
pros: World class researchers, faculty, and students. Great facilities. Depending on the department/area the work environment can be wonderful and there is opportunity to do meaningful work that makes a difference.
cons: In some areas posturing and politics is valued more highly than performance. Not always a collaborative environment. Employees or departments can often be siloed or work at odds with one another. Acclimating to the culture can be a difficult.

pros: Joel Seligman has been instrumental to positive change and growth for the UR.
cons: No ability to change careers or move up unless you graduated from there.

review_title: My experience working at university of Rochester provides me so much than I expected!
job_title: Laboratory Technician IV in Rochester, NY
pros: You gain a lot of career experiences from just working there. Urmc has everything you need in one place so you don't have to leave off site during your lunch break!
cons: This place is a big maze, their parking permit fees are very ridiculous, and not a lot of place you can park for just a couple of minutes

pros: Great faculty providing great educational experience! You get to learn a variety of subjects. And in-depth at that too. You get exposed to a good number of eclectic lectures.
cons: PR isn't so good. They need to publicize their program better, leveraging the faculty and students. Historically, this used to be a top 20 school. And they need to bring back the glory days.

pros: Largest employer in Rochester.  The University of Rochester offers a generous benefits package.  Salaries for professionals is above the average for the area.
cons: Employer sponsored healthcare has become more expensive while providing less coverage over the years.  Raises are far less than they used to be.  Parking is a huge problem despite high fees to park in poorly maintained lots.

review_title: Very effective and complete about back stabbing
pros: Pay was 20% below standard of living which is 50% above what most employers give around here.
cons: Zero training, unclear about expectations, and instead of team building and confronting employees about these issues they bcc every email to HR who advises them how to best position you for termination. Instead of working with you they work against you so that the over paid doctors can live with little consequence and continue to be uneffective without the hassle of advice.

pros: I worked for the UR College Admissions office for two successive reading seasons. The level of professionalism, competence and compassion shown by all staff is impressive. The support by not only the admissions staff but also HR and IT is comprehensive. And the pay was competitive, especially for a part-time seasonal position.
cons: I only wish that there were opportunities for this kind of employment outside of the application reading season.

pros: I appreciate not being micro managed and having flexible hours(i.e. not punching a clock). It's also busy and I'm constantly learning.
cons: Paid under market. It's really hard to get a raise beyond cost of living. There's absolutely no HR support which is shocking for such a huge organization!

pros: Good benefits  can go to school for free free health care life insurance 401 k
cons: Never closed always opening  always short not enough shift don't get respect or recegition  no days off

pros: Small and close community, high hourly salary especially in Medical Center, UR is the biggest employer in local Rochester area, and it surely provides solid environment for working.
cons: location and weather may not be your type, plus, the campus is small, the total number of students and faculty is relatively proportional to the campus size, so you can always expect to see familiar face

pros: Lot of flexibility in the job itself. Lot of opportunity to move around within the different departments at the organization.
cons: Salary is not competitive when compared to similar job titles . The benefits are slowly getting worse due to cost cutting.

pros: This is the largest employer in the city and it's affiliated with a large teaching hospital. Provides a lot of opportunities for career growth or change (for the full time employee).
cons: Tiny raises (I just got my 2.2%) and zero bonuses or incentives for the average hourly worker.

pros: The University of Rochester offers very competitive health care, retirement, and educational benefits. They are definitely among the top in Rochester in this regard.
cons: Unfortunately the starting salaries for my position were lower than the industry standard. They are not the only large employer in Rochester doing this though. Fortunately I was able to negotiate for a higher salary.

pros: Stability (the University and its accompanying hospital are the largest employers in the city of Rochester), ability to take time off when needed
cons: Bureaucracy, difficult to get around antiquated policies, the office that handles branding

pros: I had flexibility with my schedule so I could take classes at the same time. I was also given  a lot of support when I needed it. I was able to work independently and use my creativity within reason.
cons: Some jobs have ending dates or they will not employ you if you are not a student.

pros: The cost of living is pretty low so you can have a nice house with a mediocre salary.  There are some nice restaurants that you can eat at some times.
cons: The area is really depressing and you colleagues are not that good.  The restaurants aren't that great, but there is a really good one.  Panda Express is gross.

job_title: Senior Research Analyst in Rochester, NY
pros: Benefits are great.  An employee's experience really depends on what department you work in. The envirnoments can be radically different
cons: Can be very high-pressured depending on where you work.  The rules can vary greatly from dept. to dept.

job_title: Programmer Analyst Lead in Rochester, NY
pros:
Great benefits - insurance, retirement contributions, etc
Great vacation package
Strong team bond
cons:
Expensive and limited parking
Lack of leadership
Lack of loyalty shown to dedicated employees
High turnover results in extreme overwork but no managerial adjustment and no additional compensation

job_title: Health Project Coordinator in Rochester, NY
pros: They offer great benefits like tuition reimbursement program for myself, spouse and children. It's a top notch institution, so a great perk.
cons: The only con I can think of is that pay raises come few and far between. The additional benefits make up for it some, but it sucks feeling undervalued.

review_title: Great school with many resources; Collaborative atmosphere
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Rochester, NY
pros: Collaborative atmosphere which is excellent as a researcher. Lots of opportunities to present your work and receive meaningful feedback. Allowed to Audit one class a semester for free (request has to be sent in) which is great.
cons: Probably varies from department to department, but the salary for graduate research assistants in my department was low.

review_title: Decent place to work, one of the best in rochester
pros: Very good benefits, stable employment once in its easy to transfer to another job within university
cons: HR for whole university is very particular and snap to large judgments, expensive campus to get food and such, parking is terrible and advancement receives a lot of resistance even when ample proof is provided

review_title: Good Organization but some Department’s are terrible
pros: Work life Balance, flexibility, decent pay for some areas
cons: Bad Management in certain departments. No leadership. Issues don’t get addressed.  Favoring employees. No consistency or accountability.

review_title: Excellent research environment, nice nature, but boring city of Rochester with long and cold winters.
pros: Excellent conditions for research, access to all amenities on campus, good labs, good environment for outdoor activities.
cons: Not many graduate students for exchange of ideas and for socializing. Long winter, the city is boring.

review_title: Graduate student at the University of Rochester in the Biomedical Engineering Department.
pros: Laboratory interests cover a wide variety of research areas. Medical center and undergraduate campus right next to each other provide various techniques and opportunities.
cons: Compensation is low with high expected hours of work, but similar to other graduate programs. Average duration of the PhD program a bit high.

pros: Small size makes it easy to develop positive and fruitful relationships with world class faculty. The campus is also beautiful--it's a very nice place to work in the Rochester summers.
cons: The small size also can mean limited resources for graduate students. It really depends on what department and faculty member your working for--there's a lot of variation.

pros: Program is awesome. They treat their grad students in optics really well. They have a stipend that is better then many other engineering/science programs.
cons: They are a University so they have their issues. Mostly administration stuff. Occasionally have to fill out carbon copy forms which is ridiculous to me considering the other options we know have available.

job_title: Lab Technician III in Rochester, NY
pros: Very collaborative, PIs are all in communication and you can learn from more people than just your main PI
cons: If there is a problem with the PI and they are tenured/on committees, there is nothing anyone can do to hold that PI accountable.

review_title: It was great, I worked over at the LLE
pros: Working at the University of Rochester was great. I had lots of on the job training which was very relevant to my future career
cons: There were not many downsides. There are a lot of politics in management, but I was not involved with them.

pros: As a student, it is a very good opportunity to get practice as teaching is a very good way to learn and to get improved.
cons: Salary in some department is too low and sometimes spent many hours in response to students question especially before deadline.

pros: Can have great benefits if you take full advantage of the opportunities and the possibility for a flexible schedule.
cons: Hard work and going above and beyond is rarely acknowledged, very bureaucratic, views much of it's staff as expendable and does not work to retain or foster its current talent and employees.

pros: Excellent UofR Benefits & Atmosphere/Culture
cons: Lower salaries in the Finance field compared to the market. Partially made up for with better health benefits. No real opportunity for raises beyond the standard of living unless you change jobs.

pros: Friendly faculty (for the most part), free coffee in Hopeman, useful learning experiences
cons: The weather is ROUGH! Overall not much I can say about this, I have had a pretty good time here.

job_title: Health Project Coordinator in Rochester, NY
pros: The stability of knowing your job won't disappear if your company gets bought out is reassuring, and the vacation time and health insurance are pretty good.
cons: Large organizations move slowly so making changes to adapt to rapidly growing fields can be frustratingly slow.

review_title: University of Rochester: Times of great uncertainty
pros: Excellent and supportive colleagues. Great students.
cons: The University administration doesn’t seem to know how to handle crisis like the current situation with the coronavirus.

pros: access to top talent and highly intelligent colleagues, interesting and exciting things going on all the time, more fun than a corporate environment
cons: Salaries are low for student-focused staff and ratios haven't kept pace with growth of student body, sense of entitlement can get old after a while (from both faculty and students)

pros: Learn a lot, very easy to communicate with other faculty once you've gotten in a lab.
cons: compensation is poor for undergrads, maybe it's similar at other schools but one of my PIs paid under $10/hr for a research position.

pros:
Great people 
Great hours 
Good benefits 
Nice working conditions 
Good management
cons:
Far away from my place 
Sometimes really quite boring
Too quiet, but I guess that these are the downsides of working in a library

job_title: PhD In EE in Rochester, NY
pros: Nice atmosphere and working environment, diverse advanced-level strong research areas, good balance between social and cultural life, and work. Rochester is one of the most livable cities in the US. Beautiful area.
cons: Limited facility budget. Three hours driving to the closest Toronto, six hours driving to New York. Small airport with limited destinations. Cold winters.

pros: Great pay and benefits.  Being a Medical center you get 5 weeks vacation year
cons: Very Political.  Managers are allowed to bully staff. After talking to an HR counselor ( several of my colleagues had already talked to her) I was asked  was it worth it

pros: Great learning hospital with infinite opportunities! You're encouraged to continue your education at every level and get work with some of the most intelligent and enthusiastic people! Also lots of opportunity to move into different departments and could easily be a long term employer.
cons: May not want to stay in the Rochester area

review_title: A place where I met the most intelligent people of my lifetime.
pros: Good people and well established educational resources
cons: Poor consideration of student housing

pros: Amazing benefits, huge community, work for a good cause, proximity to city of Rochester.
cons: Large company, employees aren't always valued at the level they should be, not progressive socially, wage gaps for women and minorities are atrocious.

pros: Great opportunity for graduate students to earn while working. Gives students first-hand experience of earning while studying. If relevant to current stream of studies then can prove to be an internship.
cons: Have to strike a balance between work, graduate studies, homework assignments, job search and networking. That can prove to be challenging at times.

pros: The school allowed to work part time and take classes. I got to try some interesting projects and make some money at the same time.
cons: Most of the work was fairly basic and deadlines seemed very soft.

job_title: Technical Associate II in Rochester, NY
pros: The job can be intellectually rewarding with lots of flexibility and good benefits. It has been great for a working parent who is the primary care giver to school age children.
cons: This position is usually 100% dependent on federal research grants so when money is in short supply you may lose your job

job_title: Critical Care RN in Rochester, NY
pros:
Clinical Advancement System allowing RN's to move up in the company at their own pace
No mandatory floating
Tuition reimbursement of 70-80%
Housing grant of up to 9,000
Great Location
cons:
Pay for new grads range around $46-49,000
Turnover rate for certain nursing services such as ED, Med-Surg and Step Down ICU is moderate

pros: Nice People overall nice place. really good undergrads.
cons: high pressure for grants. not selecting professors for being good people but whether they can bring in lots of funding ergo there are a lot of really bad profs. that do not know general science.

pros: Good work/life balance, good benefits, extremely stable place to work. Nice wellness opportunities/facilities. Broad opportunities for work. Nice coworkers.
cons: Low pay, poor work ethic, awful parking that you have to pay for. Things move glacially. UR is very silo'ed, and each department like it's own separate workplace. Some poorly managed.

pros: Good benefits! Total compensation package can't be beat! Plenty of opportunity within college & medical center to advance.
cons: Salary on low side. Middle level management in ORACS treat you like a child.

pros: Reasonable pay, good healthcare, retirement, and decent educational benefits.  Within departments the workplace is wonderful.
cons: Upward mobility is made very difficult for many because of how HR functions.  There often seems to be a mentality of "we've always done it this way" when operating between departments, especially administrative ones.

pros: Great technology and resources. Wonderful place to learn laboratory techniques and research principles. Working at LLE is unique opportunity for undergraduate because it houses one of the world's most powerful lasers.
cons: Sometimes there is a lack of supervision and communication. Overall it is not too much of a problem though.

pros: Cordial, smart, kind people, overall a nice place to work
cons: Not much room for advancement, still a nice place to work

pros: People are well educated and very nice.The campus is very beautiful and quiet. Close to big cities on east coast.
cons: Do not like the bad weather, especially the heavy storm in winter. The builds are too old and need to build new ones

review_title: U of R strives for excellence
pros: Strong community, well-educated employees, nice location, opportunities to take classes, gain degrees, and certifications, beautiful campus near the heart of the city
cons: Terrible parking, interesting culture, difficulty working between departments, more concern with the benefit of the whole rather than the benefit of individuals

pros: Great position! Help a great of students while reviewing basics of computer science. Has been one of my best experiences at the university so far.
cons: There are no cons that exist with this position. I have enjoyed every part of being a teaching assistant .

pros: Great benefits, great tuition, great culture.
cons: A lot of red tape, not competitive salary, parking situation is horrible

review_title: Great if you have the right mentors
pros: Excellent research University, superb individual mentorships,
cons: Administrative agenda is broken and heavily foucsed on the business and profitability if a university

pros: The work environment is rochester is very good. I have So much fun doing research at the university of rochester. The faculties are helpful
cons: I don't think there are any cons related to rochester. Rochester is a good place where you have a lot of research opportunities.

pros: Good place to do research. The advisors and professors are super smart and among the best  in their field.
cons: The electrical department sometimes appears stingy as compared to CS department

job_title: Health Project Coordinator in Rochester, NY
pros: Willing to teach, very open minded. I learnt a lot in the 3 months I worked for the Chemical engineering department,
cons: Unfortunately, there are not too many fellowships, so it is difficult to get a long term job here

job_title: Doctoral Research Assistant in Rochester, NY
pros:
Small campus
Research oriented
Faculties very friendly and very helpful
the logistics resources are readily available and accessible to students
cons:
the weather here is horrible, it is mostly four to five months of snow.
The number of researchers are fewer as the size of the university is small

pros: People are always nice. Good place for families. Great community and nice scool districts. Wegmans is the best place for groceries.
cons: Parking is a little tight sometimes. However, it is not really a big problem because some other places are much worse.

review_title: Graduate student in Economics, received strong training.
pros: Good research environment, high expectations.
cons: Low funding, bad weather, not the best city.

pros: great opportunity to learn on your own and get into topics you never thought you could do as an undergrad.
cons: Very much on your own. They give you work and you need to figure it out yourself.

pros: Professor here are very enthusiastic about research and very willing to help you. You can do fantastic research here.
cons: Due to the size of the university, you can not have every equipments here to do research and need help from outside .

review_title: Good company to start your career
pros: Great department, many ways to advance. A good learning environment for recent grads who are entering the workforce.
cons:
Salary is lower than average. 
Five days workweeks with no option for working remotely from home.

review_title: Great place to get a PhD
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Rochester, NY
pros: Great instructors, good research opportunities, very supportive department with a strong well-ran administration, and  good resources available for students.
cons: The pay is low and the hours are long.

pros: You can meet some amazing people as co-workers.  Lots of hard work done well by many people.
cons: Unfortunately, humanoid robot are not perfect yet, so they are stuck with humans until perfect is achieved.

review_title: Laboratory for Laser Energetics - Sr Lab Eng
job_title: Senior Laboratory Engineer in Rochester, NY
pros: Great benefits, good work / life balance, being a part of U of R gets you some perks around town
cons: Pay is low compared to other companies, but the LLE is a research facility, so it's understandable

pros: There are good opportunities to find collaborators for research projects.
cons: Depending on the department, your satisfaction with the job may vary dramatically.

review_title: I gain a lot of communication skills and the ability to cook meals
pros: The pay was great and you also meet new people while doing so.
cons: There aren't really any cons, just greedy customers

review_title: Review of graduate student at UR
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Rochester, NY
pros: Quite, free-mind, interdisciplinary opportunities are advantages. The school has lots of great professors.
cons: The winter last four to six months. Comparing to big cities, it is a little boring and out of date.

job_title: Optics PhD Student in Rochester, NY
pros:
Very competitive stipend (optics PhD)
Good working environment environment
Great, helpful people
Sense of community
Very flexible hours
cons:
Average length of time for doctoral degree is long and increasing
Sometimes difficult to find funding
Student health insurance not included, required, and expensive given stipend amount

review_title: Patient Care tech  Environmental Service worker
job_title: Patient Care Tech in Rochester, NY
pros: I was able to provide a clean and sanitized  environment for patients and their families. Also i \I worked six years as a patient care tech.
cons: There are no cons for working at Strong Hospital..

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Rochester, NY
pros: If you were close to your grad school application but need some recommendation letters, applying to be a TA will help professors get to know you better.
cons: Too much work, TA needs to do all kinds of office hours, workshops, recitations...

pros: A growing institute, decent salary in that area, very friendly work place in a very friendly city, especially good for family.
cons: Limited career opportunity around the surrounding area other than itself, weather could be tough during the winter,

review_title: Great space to further your career
pros: It's an open environment, especially for researchers. There are many resources to take advantage of, and people are generally friendly and open to communication.
cons: Interdepartmental communication can sometimes be lacking, and the campus is fairly small.

pros: Management was awesome, my boss mostly left me to my own devices and only checked in once a week and if I did my job I was mostly left alone.
cons: Wish I was making more money

review_title: Wilson Commons is the best on-campus employer.
pros: Great staff and excellent advancement opportunities. As a student, Wilson Commons provided great experience as a manager, while still allowing adequate time to study.
cons: Occasional late nights as a manager to close building.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Rochester, NY
pros: Highly collaborative research environment, wonderful administrative staff, high caliber research, well funded research projects and PIs, dedicated graduate student population
cons: Upstate New York location, lesser well-known than lower caliber research institutions, career development more focused on undergraduates than graduates

review_title: Too much blame to go around in the facilities arena.
pros: Great pay and benefits, and friendly coworkers
cons: Believe it or not there are not enough educated managers that work in the University's facilities department.

pros: Good benefits, job security, and opportunity to contribute to the community
cons: Shuttle parking, its hard to make more money transferring departments.

pros: Lots of research opportunities and guidance from professors and other grad students
cons: Ideally, you need to be part of a research group for a while to play a significant part  in a project

job_title: Community Research Associate in Rochester, NY
pros: Strong benefits package.   Some very competent people.
cons: A large organization that isn't responsive to change.    Some people are not good at their jobs and have no incentive to change.

review_title: Great place to learn but lacks substandard place to live
pros: Great place to learn about optics.
cons: Rochester is somewhat of a disappointing town.  Everything is far apart and certain neighborhoods have surprisingly high crime rates.

pros:
